Bipolar Disorder: Depressive episodes with fatigue and hopelessness
Breast Cancer: Changes in breast shape or size
Down Syndrome: Distinctive facial features (e.g., flattened face, almond-shaped eyes)
Gallstones: Sudden, intense pain in the upper right abdomen
Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
Fever and chills (if infection is present)
Gastric Cancer: Feeling full after eating small amounts
Hepatitis A: Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
Kidney Stones: Severe pain in the back or side
Liver Cirrhosis: Swelling in the legs and abdomen
Spider-like blood vessels on the skin
Lupus: Skin rash (often butterfly-shaped on the face)
Measles: Rash that starts on the face and spreads
Migraine: Severe, throbbing headache (often on one side)
Obesity: Increased risk of related conditions (e.g., diabetes, hypertension)
Osteoporosis: Often with no symptoms until a break occurs
Ovarian Cancer: Difficulty eating or feeling full quickly
Pneumonia: Chest pain during breathing or coughing
Polio: Stiffness in the neck and back
Rabies: Severe neurological symptoms including hydrophobia and hallucinations
Skin Cancer: Skin lesions that change in color, size, or shape
Smallpox: Flu-like symptoms with characteristic pustular lesions
Stroke: Sudden numbness or weakness (especially on one side of the body)
Difficulty walking or loss of balance
Syphilis: Systemic symptoms depending on the stage
Testicular Cancer: Lump or swelling in the testicle
Dull ache in the lower abdomen or groin
Sudden fluid buildup in the scrotum
Tuberculosis (TB): Persistent cough (lasting more than three weeks)
Varicose Veins: Swollen, twisted veins (often in the legs)
Aching pain or heaviness in the legs
West Nile Virus: Severe cases can cause neurological issues (e.g., encephalitis)
Whooping Cough (Pertussis): Whooping sound when inhaling after coughing
Yellow Fever: Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
Adenovirus Infection: Common cold symptoms (runny nose, sore throat)
Anthrax: Skin sores with a black center (cutaneous anthrax)
Aortic Aneurysm: Potentially a pulsating mass due to enlargement of the aorta
Appendicitis: Sudden pain in the lower right abdomen
Arteriosclerosis: Hardening and thickening of arterial walls
Atrial Fibrillation: Risk of stroke due to disorganized electrical signals in the heart
Acanthosis Nigricans: Dark, velvety patches of skin, often in body folds such as the neck or armpits
Acute Bacterial Meningitis: Possible altered mental status due to infection of the meninges
Acute Prostatitis: Fever due to inflammation or infection of the prostate gland
Age-Related Macular Degeneration: Distorted vision due to degeneration of the macula
Alpha Thalassemia: Possible bone deformities due to reduced production of alpha-globin chains
Anaphylaxis: Swelling of the face or throat
Atopic Dermatitis: Often in the creases of the elbows and knees
Autoimmune Hepatitis: Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
Abdominal pain (especially in the upper right quadrant)
Axonal Neuropathy: Muscle weakness due to damage to the nerve axons
Behcet's Syndrome: Skin lesions due to systemic vasculitis
Benign Positional Vertigo: Episodes of dizziness triggered by specific changes in head position
Bone Marrow Disorders: Symptoms vary but may include anemia
Infections due to abnormal bone marrow function
Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy: Behavioral changes due to a prion disease in cattle
Bronchiectasis: Production of large amounts of mucus
Capillary Leak Syndrome: Fluid retention due to capillary leakage
Carcinoid Tumor: Abdominal pain (often due to serotonin secretion)
Central Serous Chorioretinopathy: Central vision loss due to fluid accumulation under the retina
Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease: Weakness in the legs, ankles, and feet
Loss of muscle bulk in the lower legs
Chronic Sinusitis: Thick nasal discharge lasting more than 12 weeks
Chronic Thromboembolic Pulmonary Hyperte: Chest pain due to high blood pressure in the lungs from old blood clots
Cirrhosis of the Liver: Liver dysfunction due to chronic liver damage and scarring
Classic Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome: Fragile tissues due to collagen defects
Cold Urticaria: Itching in response to cold exposure
Complex Regional Pain Syndrome: Changes in skin color and temperature, usually in an arm or leg following an injury
Constrictive Pericarditis: Swelling in the legs and abdomen
Deep Vein Thrombosis: Redness in the leg due to a blood clot
Dermatitis Herpetiformis: Typically on elbows, knees, and buttocks
Dry Mouth Syndrome: Potential difficulty speaking or swallowing due to reduced saliva production
Echinococcosis: Symptoms related to liver or lung cysts
Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome Type IV: Risk of internal bleeding due to collagen defects
Familial Amyloid Polyneuropathy: Organ damage due to abnormal protein deposits
Functional Gastrointestinal Disorders: Altered bowel habits without a structural cause
Genital Herpes: Painful sores or blisters in the genital area caused by herpes simplex virus
Guillain-Barre Syndrome: Weakness and tingling in the legs
Ascending paralysis (spreading to the upper body)
Haemochromatosis: Skin discoloration due to iron overload in the body
Hemophilia: Joint pain and swelling (due to bleeding into the joints)
Prolonged bleeding after injuries or surgeries
Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: Leading to symptoms like shortness of breath and chest pain
Ichthyosis Vulgaris: Dry, scaly skin due to genetic defects affecting skin barrier function
Interstitial Cystitis: Pain that worsens with a full bladder
Iron Overload: Liver damage due to excessive iron accumulation in the body
Legg-Calve-Perthes Disease: Joint stiffness in children due to temporary loss of blood supply to the femoral head
Lymphangiectasia: Malabsorption due to dilation of lymphatic vessels
Nephrotic Syndrome: Swelling (especially around the eyes and in the legs)
Paraneoplastic Syndrome: Symptoms related to cancer but not directly caused by the tumor
Actinomycosis: Painful, abscess-like lesions, usually in the mouth or jaw
Acute Coronary Syndrome: Nausea due to reduced blood flow to the heart
Acute Glomerulonephritis: Swelling due to inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys
Acute Myocarditis: Shortness of breath due to inflammation of the heart muscle
Adrenal Cortex Cancer: Hormonal imbalances due to malignant tumors in the adrenal glands
Agenesis of the Kidney: Absence of one or both kidneys
Potential renal failure or developmental issues
Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency: Lung disease symptoms (cough, shortness of breath)
Alport Syndrome: Hearing loss due to genetic defects affecting the kidneys and ears
Benign Brain Tumors: Neurological deficits due to non-cancerous growths in the brain
Biliary Colic: Severe abdominal pain due to gallstones obstructing the bile ducts
Chagas Disease: Acute symptoms include fever and swelling
Chronic symptoms can involve heart and gastrointestinal issues
Chemical Burns: Pain from exposure to harmful chemicals
Chronic Hepatitis: Abdominal pain due to long-term liver inflammation
Chronic Pelvic Pain: Persistent pain in the pelvic region
Chronic Urticaria: Redness lasting more than six weeks
Cystic Hygroma: Soft, fluid-filled lumps (usually in the neck or armpit area)
Deafness: Partial or complete loss of hearing
Dental Caries: Cavities due to bacterial damage to the teeth
Diphtheria: Thick gray or white coating in the throat or nose
Dry Eye Syndrome: Excessive tearing due to inadequate lubrication
Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome: Skin that is easily bruised and stretches easily
Endocrine Disruptor Exposure: Associated health effects from chemicals interfering with endocrine function
Esophageal Atresia: Choking in infants due to an incomplete esophagus
Essential Tremor: Tremors in the hands, arms, or head
Difficulty with fine motor tasks (e.g., writing)
Worsening of tremors with stress or fatigue
Fabry Disease: Pain in the hands and feet
Farber Disease: Progressive neurological symptoms due to enzyme deficiency
Galactorrhea: Unintentional milk production from the breasts
Granuloma Annulare: Often on the hands and feet
Haemorrhagic Fever with Renal Syndrome: Kidney damage due to viral infections from rodent-borne viruses
Hailey-Hailey Disease: Blistering and erosions of the skin
Hereditary Angioedema: Recurrent swelling of the limbs, face, or intestines
Difficulty breathing (if swelling affects the airways)
Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia: Red spots on skin and mucous membranes
Hyperhidrosis: Often affecting the hands, feet, or underarms
Hypochondriasis: Excessive worry about having a serious illness despite lack of medical evidence
Hypoglycemic Coma: Loss of consciousness due to extremely low blood sugar levels
Insulin Resistance: Potential development of type 2 diabetes due to ineffective insulin use
Jarisch-Herxheimer Reaction: Worsening of symptoms after starting antibiotic treatment for syphilis
Jejunal Atresia: Feeding intolerance due to a blockage in the jejunum
Korsakoff Syndrome: Often associated with chronic alcohol use
Lipoedema: Symmetrical swelling of the legs and buttocks
Metabolic Syndrome: A cluster of conditions including high blood pressure
Excess body fat around the waist
Miller Fisher Syndrome: Areflexia due to a variant of Guillain-Barre syndrome
Mitochondrial Disease: Symptoms vary widely but can include muscle weakness
Multicentric Castleman Disease: Lymph node enlargement due to a rare lymphoproliferative disorder
Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia: Tumors in multiple endocrine glands (such as thyroid, parathyroid, and adrenal glands)
Paget's Disease of the Breast: Discharge due to a rare form of breast cancer
Agnosia: Difficulty recognizing objects, sounds, or faces despite intact sensory organs
Aneurysms: Symptoms depend on location; can include pain, swelling, or sudden severe symptoms if ruptured
Anorectal Malformation: Abnormal development of the anus and rectum
Issues with bowel movements in infants
Aortic Valve Stenosis: Fatigue due to obstruction of blood flow from the heart
Apraxia: Difficulty with motor planning and execution despite understanding the task and having the ability to perform it
Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Dis: Kidney failure due to cyst formation
Brachial Plexus Injury: Arm weakness or paralysis due to nerve damage in the brachial plexus
Candidiasis: White patches in the mouth or throat
Redness and soreness in the affected area
Vaginal itching and discharge (in vaginal candidiasis)
Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Numbness or tingling in the fingers or hand
Pain in the wrist or hand
Cavernous Malformation: Neurological deficits due to vascular malformations in the brain
Chronic Migraine: Often with nausea and sensitivity to light
Cicatricial Pemphigoid: Chronic blistering and scarring of mucous membranes and skin
Cytomegalovirus Retinitis: Potential loss of vision due to viral infection
Esophageal Spasm: Episodes of intense pain in the esophagus
Factor V Leiden Mutation: Increased risk of abnormal blood clotting
Leading to deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism
Haemophilus Influenzae Type B (Hib) Dise: Potentially severe infections like meningitis in children
Haemophilia A: Prolonged bleeding due to Factor VIII deficiency
Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syn: Increased risk of breast, ovarian, and other cancers
Insulinoma: Confusion due to insulin-secreting pancreatic tumors
Keloids: Raised, thickened scars that extend beyond the original wound
Krabbe Leukodystrophy: Developmental delays due to a genetic disorder
Latent Tuberculosis Infection: Asymptomatic but can develop into active tuberculosis if untreated
Lymphedema: Swelling in the limbs or other areas due to lymph fluid accumulation
Marasmus: Muscle wasting due to inadequate calorie intake
Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma: Symptoms of thyroid cancer originating from C cells
Mumps: Possible complications like orchitis or meningitis
Myoclonus: Sudden, involuntary muscle jerks or twitches
Paraneoplastic Syndromes: Symptoms vary depending on the underlying cancer but can include weight loss, fever, and skin changes
Agoraphobia: Fear of situations where escape might be difficult
Avoidance of places like crowds or open spaces
Alopecia Areata: Often on the scalp or beard
Amblyopia: Not correctable by glasses or contact lenses
Arnold-Chiari Malformation: Balance problems due to cerebellar herniation
Benign Tumors: Symptoms vary based on location; may include swelling or pain
Bilateral Renal Agenesis: Severe renal failure and complications in newborns
Brainstem Glioma: Possibly problems with breathing or heart rate
Bulimia Nervosa: Episodes of binge eating followed by purging
Carcinoma in Situ: Early-stage cancer that hasn't invaded surrounding tissues
May not show symptoms until later stages
Chronic Cough: Persistent cough lasting more than eight weeks
Chronic Granulomatous Disease: Recurrent bacterial and fungal infections (particularly in the lungs and skin)
Cushing's Syndrome: Weight gain (especially around the abdomen and face)
Purple stretch marks on the skin
Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus: Typically a butterfly-shaped rash on the face
Dermatomyositis: Skin rash (often on the face, knuckles, or around the eyes)
Endocarditis: Swelling in the legs, feet, or abdomen
Epidermolysis Bullosa: Blisters in the mouth and throat
Thickened skin on the palms and soles
Focal Brain Lesions: May include neurological deficits or seizures
Gastritis: Vomiting due to inflammation of the stomach lining
Herpes Zoster: Painful rash in a dermatomal distribution
Hirschsprung Disease: Abdominal distention in infants due to lack of nerve cells in the colon
Holoprosencephaly: Leading to facial deformities and neurological issues
Intrauterine Growth Restriction: Resulting in low birth weight and possible complications at birth
Leprosy: Nerve damage (leading to loss of sensation)
Lichen Planus: Itchy, purple rash on skin and mucous membranes
Lymphatic Filariasis: Swelling and pain in limbs or genitals due to parasitic infection
Lymphocytic Leukemia: Enlarged lymph nodes due to cancer of lymphocytes
Mycobacterial Infections: Weight loss associated with infections like tuberculosis
Myofascial Pain Syndrome: Often with referred pain to other areas
Anaplastic Astrocytoma: Neurological deficits depending on tumor location
Bell's Palsy: Sudden weakness or paralysis on one side of the face
Loss of the ability to taste
Eye irritation (due to inability to close the eye)
Cavernous Hemangioma: Pain or functional impairment if large
Cervical Spondylotic Myelopathy: Numbness or weakness in the arms
Dandy-Walker Malformation: Enlarged fourth ventricle in the brain
Dandy-Walker Variant: Similar to Dandy-Walker Malformation but with less pronounced symptoms
Horner's Syndrome: Anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on one side of the face
Hypophosphatemia: Respiratory difficulties due to low phosphate levels
Inherited Metabolic Disorders: Symptoms vary widely but may include developmental delay
Klebsiella Pneumonia: Chest pain due to bacterial lung infection
Medulloblastoma: Symptoms of increased intracranial pressure in children
Myeloma: Bone pain (especially in the spine or chest)
Non-Communicable Diseases: Chronic conditions such as cardiovascular diseases
Pectus Excavatum: Sometimes with associated respiratory or cardiac symptoms
Pemphigus Vulgaris: Painful blisters and sores on the skin and mucous membranes
Raynaud's Phenomenon: Color changes in the fingers and toes
Often triggered by cold or stress
Systemic Sclerosis: Similar to scleroderma with systemic involvement including skin, joints, and internal organs
Apnea of Prematurity: Intermittent cessation of breathing in premature infants
Beriberi: Numbness in the hands and feet
Broca's Aphasia: Difficulty with speech production while comprehension remains relatively intact
Bruton's Agammaglobulinemia: Frequent infections due to low antibody levels
Bullous Pemphigoid: Large, tense blisters on the skin
Endocrine Tumors: Symptoms vary depending on the gland affected
Hemangioma: Sometimes associated with swelling or pain
Hidradenitis Suppurativa: Skin infections in areas with hair follicles
Large Vessel Vasculitis: Symptoms related to affected large arteries
Paget's Disease: Fractures due to abnormal bone remodeling
Arterial Thrombosis: Potential loss of function in the affected limb or organ
Atherosclerosis: Symptoms related to reduced blood flow in arteries
Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo: Brief episodes of dizziness or spinning triggered by changes in head position
Cleidocranial Dysplasia: Abnormal development of bones in the skull and clavicles
Ectodermal Dysplasia: Abnormalities of skin, hair, nails, and teeth
Erythroderma: Widespread redness and inflammation of the skin
Goodpasture Syndrome: Swelling in the legs or ankles
IgG4-Related Disease: Often with a history of autoimmune conditions
Neonatal Jaundice: Yellowing of the skin and eyes in newborns
Ocular Melanoma: Sometimes a noticeable mass in the eye
Brown-Sequard Syndrome: Loss of sensation and motor function on one side of the body
Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Dilated Cardiomyopathy: Swelling in the legs and abdomen
Herpes Simplex Virus Infection: Painful sores or blisters on the lips
Human Papillomavirus Infection: Warts in the mouth or throat
Impetigo: Red sores that rupture, ooze, and form a yellow-brown crust
Red spots or blisters (especially around the mouth and nose)
Inclusion Body Myositis: Particularly in the arms and legs
Kaposi Sarcoma: Often with lymph node or internal organ involvement
Aortitis: Symptoms related to aortic insufficiency or stenosis
Arachnoiditis: Possibly loss of sensation or mobility
Bartonella Infection: Possible lymphadenopathy (often associated with cat scratch fever)
Bladder Exstrophy: Exposure of the bladder outside the body
Capgras Syndrome: Belief that loved ones have been replaced by impostors or duplicates
Delusional Parasitosis: Belief that one is infested with parasites
Discoid Lupus Erythematosus: Scaly, red skin rash on the face and scalp
Inborn Errors of Metabolism: Symptoms vary widely depending on the specific metabolic disorder
Malignant Melanoma: Changes in a mole or skin lesion
Mobius Syndrome: Inability to move the eyes laterally
Neuroendocrine Tumor: Symptoms vary depending on tumor location
Odontogenic Cyst: Sometimes a palpable mass in the jaw
Oral Lichen Planus: White, lacy patches or painful sores in the mouth
Autoimmune Gastritis: Anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency
Bone Marrow Aspiration: Procedure-related discomfort (pain and bruising at the aspiration site)
Diabetes Mellitus Type 3c: Symptoms similar to diabetes mellitus (due to pancreatic damage affecting insulin production)
Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy: Muscle weakness (starting in the legs and pelvis)
Frontal Lobe Epilepsy: Seizures originating in the frontal lobe
Ganglion Cyst: Non-cancerous lump (usually on the wrist or hand)
Hemangioblastoma: Symptoms related to pressure on nearby structures
Hyperphenylalaninemia: Musty odor of the urine (in phenylketonuria)
Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis: Muscle weakness or paralysis (usually associated with low potassium levels)
Keratosis Pilaris: Small, rough bumps on the skin (often on the arms or thighs)
Meningioma: Neurological deficits depending on the tumor's location
Mitochondrial Diabetes: Symptoms similar to type 2 diabetes (with a mitochondrial genetic basis)
Paraneoplastic Neurological Syndromes: Neurological symptoms associated with cancer (such as ataxia or myoclonus)
Perioral Dermatitis: Red, bumpy rash around the mouth, nose, and eyes
Pyoderma Gangrenosum: Painful, rapidly growing skin ulcers with a purulent base
Restless Legs Syndrome: Often accompanied by an urge to move them
Postherpetic Neuralgia: Sensitivity in areas previously affected by shingles
Precocious Puberty: Early onset of secondary sexual characteristics
Pre-eclampsia: Swelling of hands and feet during pregnancy
Prolactinoma: Decreased libido and erectile dysfunction in men
Prurigo Nodularis: Itchy nodules or bumps on the skin
Often in areas subjected to scratching
Pyloric Stenosis: A palpable abdominal mass in infants
Radioulnar Synostosis: Deformity where the radius and ulna fuse
Rectal Prolapse: Protrusion of the rectum through the anus
Restless Leg Syndrome: Uncomfortable sensations in the legs with an urge to move them
Rickets: Delayed growth in children due to vitamin D deficiency
Sacroiliitis: Pain in the lower back and buttocks
Scimitar Syndrome: Right-sided heart failure symptoms such as dyspnea and cyanosis
Shigella Infection: Sometimes with blood or mucus in stools
Silent Thyroiditis: Often without clear signs of thyroid inflammation
Silicosis: Lung fibrosis due to silica dust exposure
Spina Bifida: Birth defect with varying symptoms including lower limb weakness
Sporotrichosis: Lymphatic swelling following a puncture wound
Status Epilepticus: Prolonged seizures without recovery between episodes
Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: Drop in blood pressure when lying on the back
Synovial Sarcoma: Painful mass or swelling near a joint
Takayasu's Arteritis: Symptoms of decreased blood flow to various organs
Tendinitis: Pain and tenderness around a tendon
Teratoma: Tumor with a variety of tissue types
Thoracic Aortic Aneurysm: Symptoms of pressure on nearby structures
Tinea Versicolor: Discolored patches on the skin that may be lighter or darker than surrounding areas
Trigeminal Neuralgia: Severe, sudden facial pain along the trigeminal nerve distribution
Trypanosomiasis (Chagas Disease): Chronic symptoms including heart and digestive issues
Urticaria (Hives): Itchy, raised welts on the skin
Melanoma: Changes in a mole or skin lesion
Meniere's Disease: A feeling of fullness in the ear
Metatarsalgia: Pain and inflammation in the ball of the foot
Molluscum Contagiosum: Dome-shaped papules with a central dimple
Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Si: Elevated blood proteins detected on routine testing
Mucormycosis: Black necrotic tissue in severe cases
Mycetoma: Often with discharge of grains or seeds
Myoclonic Epilepsy: Brief jerks of muscles or muscle groups
Myocarditis: Swelling in the legs or abdomen
Necrotizing Fasciitis: Severe pain in the affected area
Paraneoplastic Pemphigus: Erosions on skin and mucous membranes
Pemphigoid Gestationis: Often starting around the abdomen and spreading
Pilonidal Cyst: Pain and swelling near the tailbone
Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome: Muscle aches (especially in the hips, back, and shoulders)
Hyperemesis Gravidarum: Severe nausea and vomiting during pregnancy
Infantile Spasms: Clusters of spasms (often occurring upon waking)
Lipoma: Soft, movable lumps under the skin
Aneurysm: Symptoms depending on location (e.g., headache for brain aneurysms)
Angina: Often radiating to the arm, neck, or jaw
Angioedema: Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat
Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BP: Balance issues triggered by head movements
Bowen's Disease: Red, scaly patches or plaques on the skin
Cholelithiasis (Gallstones): Abdominal pain, especially after eating fatty foods
Chondrosarcoma: Pain at the site of the tumor (usually worse at night)
Swelling or a lump at the site
Fractures (if the bone is weakened by the tumor)
Reduced range of motion in the affected limb
Coarctation of the Aorta: High blood pressure in the upper body
Weak pulse in the lower body
Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS): Changes in skin color and temperature
Cyclothymic Disorder: Periods of hypomania and mild depression
De Quervain's Tenosynovitis: Pain and swelling at the base of the thumb
Dravet Syndrome: Severe, prolonged seizures starting in infancy
Dupuytren's Contracture: Thickening and shortening of the palmar fascia
Leading to flexion deformities of the fingers
Erythema Nodosum: Painful, red nodules on the shins
Pemphigus: Painful blisters and sores on the skin and mucous membranes
Pityriasis Rosea: Rash, typically starting with a single large spot (herald patch) followed by smaller spots
Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD): Avoidance of reminders of the trauma
Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy: Changes in skin color and temperature
Sarcoma: Sometimes impaired function of the affected area
Shingles (Herpes Zoster): Painful rash typically on one side of the body
Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS): Sudden and unexplained death of an infant
Syncope: Often with a brief episode of dizziness or light-headedness before
Thrombocytopenia: Petechiae (small red or purple spots on the skin)
Tinea Corporis: Itchy or ring-shaped rash with a clear center and red or scaly edges
Tinea Cruris: Itchy or red rash in the groin area with well-defined edges
Barrett's Esophagus: Regurgitation of food or sour liquid
Cat Scratch Disease: Swollen lymph nodes (especially near the site of a scratch or bite)
Blisters or bumps at the scratch site
Conjunctivitis (Pink Eye): Redness in the white of the eye or inner eyelid
Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Pain or tenderness in the leg
Red or discolored skin on the leg
Degenerative Disc Disease: Chronic pain in the lower back or neck
Pain that worsens with sitting or bending or lifting or twisting
Numbness or tingling in the arms or legs
Diverticulitis: Abdominal pain (usually on the left side)
Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP): Development of numerous polyps in the colon and rectum
Fifth Disease: Red rash on the face (slapped cheek appearance)
Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV): Painful blisters or ulcers at the site of infection e.g. mouth or genitals
Itching or tingling in the affected area
Huntington's Chorea: Muscle problems e.g. rigidity or contracture
Intracranial Hemorrhage: Weakness on one side of the body
Jaundice: Yellowing of the skin and eyes
